ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
NOTES: On 23 April 2023, FARDC-MONUSCO clashed against ADF in Apetinasana (Oicha, Beni, Nord-Kivu) for the third consecutive day. Casualties unknown.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
NOTES: On 22 April 2023, FARDC-MONUSCO clashed against ADF in Apetinasana (Oicha, Beni, Nord-Kivu) for the second consecutive day. Casualties unknown.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
NOTES: On 21 April 2023, began the first day of joint FARDC-MONUSCO operations against ADF in Apetinasana (Oicha, Beni, Nord-Kivu). Casualties unknown.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 20 April 2023, 'hundreds' of residents of Masisi town attacked and stoned a MONUSCO convoy in Masisi (Osso, Masisi, Nord-Kivu).

ACTOR1: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: CODECO: Cooperative for Development of Congo
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Chini Ya Kilima-FPIC: Patriotic and Integrationist Force of Congo; Bira Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
NOTES: On 17 April 2023, approximately a hundred CODECO and FPIC members (including girls and women) symbolically laid down their weapons in Diango cantonment site, 10 kilometers from Bunia (Baboa-Bakoe, Irumu, Ituri) during the official launch of the DDR operation in Ituri province. After surrendering their weapons the combatants underwent identification and verification to receive their demobilization cards. The provincial governor, military authorities and MONUSCO were present. 14 weapons were seized on this first day of demobilization (3 AK-47s, 10 AK-56s, 1 Uzi), along with 795 rounds of ammunition, 2 rockets, 2 hand grenades and 24 magazines.

ACTOR1: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
ACTOR2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 14 April 2023, ADF clashed against FARDC and MONUSCO in Ndalya (Walese Vonkutu, Irumu, Ituri). Casualties unknown.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 13 April 2023, residents demonstrated against the presence of MONUSCO in Mungamba (Walese Vonkutu, Irumu, Ituri), who they said they suspected of collaborating with ADF. The protesters blocked the road to the convoy (means unspecified). MONUSCO fired shots in the air to disperse the protesters and left. No casualties.

ACTOR1: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
ACTOR2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Around 12 April 2023 (week of), ADF clashed against FARDC and MONUSCO in Lolwa (Bakwanza, Mambasa, Ituri). Casualties unknown.

ACTOR1: Mayi Mayi Militia (Yira)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
SOURCE: Actualite; Bunia Actualite; Politico (DRC); Radio Okapi
NOTES: On 10 April 2023, Mayi Mayi Yira attacked a MONUSCO convoy in Mihobwe, a village located 'a couple of kilometers south' of Lubero (Baswaga, Lubero, Nord-Kivu), on the RN2. The assailants shot at the convoy and the peacekeepers returned fire. They were supported by FARDC soldiers. Attackers fled. 3 Mayi Mayi Yira were injured.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
SOURCE: Bunia Actualite; Election-Net; Mediacongo.net; Politico (DRC); Radio Okapi; Virunga Business Radio
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 6 April 2023, MONUSCO closed down its military base in Kamango (Watalinga, Beni, Nord-Kivu). The base was established 10 years ago in response to ADF insecurity. MONUSCO said it withdrew from the area following the return of peace and security, and in accordance with the Transition Plan, which plans a gradual exit of MONUSCO from DRC.

ACTOR1: M23: March 23 Movement
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 11 March 2023, for the second day, M23 shelled MONUSCO military base in Mubambiro (Bahunde, Masisi, Nord-Kivu). Casualties unknown. Reports unconfirmed.

ACTOR1: M23: March 23 Movement
ACTOR2: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 24 February 2023, MONUSCO handed over 7 M23 combatants to the national DDR program in Kanyaruchinya [location coded in Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu)]. The combatants surrendered with weapons.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Other: On 17 February 2023, MONUSCO closed down its base in Mutwanga (Ruwenzori, Beni, Nord-Kivu); as part of its transition plan which calls for a gradual withdrawal of the mission out of DRC. MONUSCO cited improved security in the area.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Refugees/IDPs (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
SOURCE: 7 Sur 7; Actualite; AFP; Bunia Actualite; Kivu Times; La Libre Afrique; La Prosperite; La Prunelle; Mediacongo.net; Politico (DRC); Radio Okapi; Reuters; RFI; RTNC; Rwanda News Agency; SOS Medias; Twitter; Xinhua
NOTES: On 7 February 2023, rioters, mainly IDPs, targeted a MONUSCO convoy in Kanyaruchinya, 2 kilometers from Munigi (Bukumu, Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu) during a demonstration against inaction of the EAC force. The group barricaded the road with rocks and threw stones at the convoy coming from Goma, set fire to the four vehicles and seized the cargo on board. MONUSCO, assisted by FARDC, shot at the rioters who wanted to seize what they thought were weapons on board. MONUSCO said 3 civilians (all IDPs) died in the 'scuffle', while the Congolese government and army, including the Governor, said it was 8 (and that 28 people were wounded). 3-8 fatalities coded as 3.

ACTOR1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
SOURCE: 7 Sur 7; Actu30; Actualite; AFP; Bunia Actualite; Election-Net; La Prunelle; Mediacongo.net; MONUSCO; Politico (DRC); Radio Okapi; Reuters; RFI; SOS Medias; Twitter
NOTES: On 5 February 2023, an unidentified armed group launched strikes at a MONUSCO helicopter over Rusayo (Bukumu, Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu). The helicopter managed to land in Goma (Goma, Goma, Nord-Kivu). The pilot was killed and another Blue Helmet was wounded. The DRC government blamed M23 for the strikes. The group denied the accusation, saying the strikes were launched from outside of the territories controlled by M23.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: M23: March 23 Movement
NOTES: Defusal: Around 2 February 2023, civilians discovered 12 landmines left by M23 in three locations of Bwisha chiefdom (Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu). Eight in Rugari groupement; three at the Kanzanza Catholic church in Buramba and one landmine in Kisharu/Kisharo. The explosived are assumed to have been controlled by the FARDC or the MONUSCO.

ACTOR1: Civilians (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Refugees/IDPs (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
SOURCE: 7 Sur 7; Actualite; Mediacongo.net; Politico (DRC); Radio Okapi; Top Congo FM Kinshasa; Xinhua
NOTES: Displacement: On 26 January 2023, around 450 IDPs, including women and children, fled the M23 who gained control of the city of Kitchanga and sheltered in and around MONUSCO base in Kitchanga (Bwito, Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu). Some claimed MONUSCO refused the access to refugees to the base whilst MONUSCO spokesperson denied. MONUSCO also declared they provided first aid, water, and tents to the IDPs.

ACTOR1: M23: March 23 Movement
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 21 January 2023, overnight, 'a few' (number unspecified) Congolese M23 combatants surrendered to the MONUSCO base in Kiwanja (Rutshuru, Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu).

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Refugees/IDPs (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
SOURCE: Actualite; Bunia Actualite; Kivu Security Tracker; La Libre Afrique; Mediacongo.net; Radio Okapi
NOTES: On 19 January 2023, IDPs violently demonstrated at a MONUSCO base in Bule (Bahema-Badjere, Djugu, Ituri), denouncing MONUSCO inaction following a deadly CODECO-URDPC (alleged perpetrators) attack on nearby Plaine Savo IDPs camp (coded separately). They threw stones at the peacekeepers who retaliated with live fire, injuring 16 people (five according to MONUSCO). The head of the local health center said one demonstrator had a bullet injury and 15 others were injured by barbed wire. Three blue helmets were lightly injured, according to MONUSCO.

ACTOR1: Mayi Mayi Militia (Yakutumba)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Mayi Mayi Militia (Toronto)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Around 13 January 2023 (as reported), 15 combatants (including four women) from the Toronto-led faction of Mayi Mayi Yakutumba surrendered to the Uvira branch of the Disarmament, Demobilization, Community Rehabilitation and Stabilization Program, coded to Uvira (Uvira, Uvira, Sud-Kivu). The combatants came with 6 weapons (AK-47s and a revolver) and two loaded magazines. The combatants were operating in Fizi territory.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: CODECO: Cooperative for Development of Congo
NOTES: On 12 January 2023, FARDC clashed against CODECO in Djodjo/Dodjo forest (Walendu-Djatsi, Djugu, Ituri). MONUSCO intervened to assist FARDC. Casualties unknown. CODECO combatants fled in the forest.

ACTOR1: Civilians (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Women (Democratic Republic of Congo); Refugees/IDPs (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Other: On 10 January 2023, MONUSCO evacuated 200 women who were surrounded by CODECO in Logotapka, a village in Djugu territory, coded to territorial capital Djugu (Walendu-Djatsi, Djugu, Ituri). The women had left the Rhoo IDP camp to find food; MONUSCO repatriated them to the camp.

ACTOR1: CODECO: Cooperative for Development of Congo
ACTOR2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
SOURCE: 7 Sur 7; Actualite; Kivu Security Tracker; Kivu Times; La Libre Afrique; Mediacongo.net; Twitter
NOTES: On 8 January 2023, CODECO clashed with FARDC and MONUSCO in Jisa (Bahema-Nord, Djugu, Ituri) and in Drodro, Largu, Djuda, Blukwa, Rhoo, Mbi, Nzengele and Ngazba (coded separately). At least 23 fatalities, including FARDC and civilians. Several people wounded. According to several sources, CODECO's assault unfolded after the killing of a Lendu affiliated teacher during the morning of this 8 January in Blukwa by FPAC/Zaire (coded separately). At least 23 fatalities split across 8 locations, coded as 3.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
SOURCE: Deutsche Welle; Radio Okapi; RFI; Twitter
NOTES: Non-violent activity: On 4 January 2023, MONUSCO, in partnership with FARDC, launched a new operation called 'Linda Njia' ('to protect the road', in Swahili) to ensure the protection of civilians along the Beni-Semuliki-Kamango-Nobili axis in Beni territory (coded to territorial capital Beni, Nord-Kivu). The operation is intended to 'prevent and dissuade' armed groups from attacking civilians along the road and will be led by the MONUSCO Force Intervention Brigade (FIB), which has an offensive mandate.

ACTOR1: CODECO: Cooperative for Development of Congo
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Lendu Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-); MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 4 January 2023, CODECO freed 18-19 hostages in Bunia (Bunia, Ituri). 13 hostages were handed over to local authorities alongside FARDC and MONUSCO, and the remaining 5 were handed over to the administrator of Djugu territory. The group of 13 had been abducted on 23 December (coded separately). No further information about the date of abduction of the remaining 5. Authorities did not specify whether a ransom had been paid for the liberation of the hostages.

ACTOR1: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Banyamulenge Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
NOTES: On 31 December 2022, a Twirwaneho combatant handed himself over to MONUSCO in Bijombo groupement (Bavira, Uvira, Sud-Kivu), still in his military outfit and with a loaded AK-47. He was subsequently transferred to the provincial branch of the national DDR program (PDDDRC-S).

ACTOR1: M23: March 23 Movement
ACTOR2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-); EAC: East African Community; ICGLR: International Conference on the Great Lakes Region
SOURCE: 7 Sur 7; Kivu Times; Mediacongo.net; Radio Okapi; SOS Medias; Twitter
NOTES: Other: On 13 December 2022, the M23, the leadership of the EAC joint force, the joint verification mechanism of the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region (ICGLR) and MONUSCO met in Kibumba (Bukumu, Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu). M23 declared having had the guarantee by the EAC joint force leadership that they won't be attacked in case of withdrawal. M23 also declared being waiting for the next meeting which is not planned as per the FARDC.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)

ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-) Military Police
SOURCE: Actualite; Bunia Actualite; Virunga Business Radio
NOTES: On 9 December 2022, IDPs temporarily located at Kanyaruchinya camp, in Rukoko (Bukumu, Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu) set up barricades and attempted to set a UN convoy on fire. The peacekeepers (MONUSCO) and the military police shot at the group (means unknown/not mentioned) which resulted into 1 civilian killed and several injured.

ACTOR1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 19 November 2022, an unidentified armed group ambushed and abducted 5 MONUSCO driving a vehicle near Lusenda (Mutambala, Fizi, Sud-Kivu), coded to Lweba. FARDC freed the hostages after a clash with the group later on (coded separately).

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Other: On 10 November 2022, MONUSCO officially closed its office and withdrew its last contingent from Shabunda territory (coded to territorial capital Shabunda, Bakisi, Shabunda, Sud-Kivu), citing improved security and state presence in the area.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Civilians (Democratic Republic of Congo); Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-); Journalists (Democratic Republic of Congo); Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-); Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
NOTES: Displacement: Around 2 November 2022 (from 28 - 5 November), MONUSCO evacuated 139 people from recently-conquered MONUSCO zones, from its base in Kiwanja towards Goma (Goma, Goma, Nord-Kivu). The 139 people included 64 civilians (government officials, journalists, human rights defenders, etc.) who had been threatened by M23, 74 FARDC and one police officer.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Refugees/IDPs (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
SOURCE: ReliefWeb; Twitter; Actualite; SOS Medias; La Prunelle; Reuters; Radio Okapi; Mediacongo.net; AFP; Africa News
NOTES: On 1 November 2022, IDPs based at Kanyaruchynia camp stoned a MONUSCO convoy at Kanyaruchynia military checkpoint near Rukoko (Bukumu, Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu). The convoy was returning from Rutshuru territory and heading towards Goma before it was stopped 8km away from the city. The rioters also burnt 2 MONUSCO vehicles. 2 Bangladeshi blue helmets were injured. Peacekeepers fired in the air to disperse the crowd. According to some sources, the rioters suspected that the convoy carried rebels.

ACTOR1: M23: March 23 Movement
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 1 November 2022, M23 shelled two mortars in direction of a MONUSCO patrol near Rugari (Bwisha, Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu). Casualties unknown.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: Civilians (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Journalists (Democratic Republic of Congo)
NOTES: Other: On 31 October 2022, MONUSCO exfiltrated 12 journalists by helicopter from Rutshuru to Goma (Nord-Kivu). Those journalists were operating in newly occupied zones by the M23 where they were threatened. Since the resumption of the M23 conflict on 20 October 2022, at least 30 journalists have fled in a MONUSCO base for protection purposes.

ACTOR1: M23: March 23 Movement
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
SOURCE: 7 Sur 7; Twitter; La Prosperite; La Libre Afrique; Kivu Security Tracker; SOS Medias; Politico (DRC); RFI; La Prunelle; Radio Okapi
NOTES: On 29 October 2022, M23 took control of Rutshuru town (Rutshuru, Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu), after a clash against MONUSCO and FARDC. M23 leaders reportedly held popular rallies calling on local population to return and resume their activities freely. Casualties unknown.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 29 October 2022, an altercation broke out between youth and MONUSCO in Goma (Goma, Goma, Nord-Kivu). The youths tried attacking a MONUSCO convoy; the blue helmets retaliated by opening fire. The event happened in the context of anti-MONUSCO sentiment in the area. No fatalities.

ACTOR1: M23: March 23 Movement
ACTOR2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
SOURCE: Bunia Actualite; Kivu Security Tracker; Politico (DRC); Reuters; RFI; Twitter
NOTES: On 29 October 2022, M23 overtook Rumangabo military camp (Bwisha, Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu) after fire exchange with FARDC and MONUSCO, who retreated and put up a very limited resistance. MONUSCO announced several days later they had operated a 'strategic and tactical withdrawal from Rumangabo'.

ACTOR1: M23: March 23 Movement
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
SOURCE: 7 Sur 7; AFP; Bunia Actualite; Kivu Security Tracker; Kivu Times; La Libre Afrique; La Prosperite; La Prunelle; Mediacongo.net; Politico (DRC); Radio Okapi; Reuters; RFI; SOS Medias; Twitter
NOTES: On 29 October 2022, M23 took control of Kiwanja (Rutshuru, Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu), after a clash against MONUSCO and FARDC. M23 leaders reportedly held popular rallies calling on local population to return and resume their activities freely. 4 blue helmets wounded (2 by mortar fire and 2 others by small arms) and at least 3 civilians were killed. Some M23 combatants reportedly wore uniforms similar to those of the Rwandan army.

ACTOR1: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
ACTOR2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Defusal: On 25 October 2022, one to two explosive devices planted by ADF were found in Oicha market (Beni, Nord-Kivu). FARDC, alongside the United Nations Mine Action Service of MONUSCO reached the location to deactivate the bombs.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Other: On 24 October 2022, MONUSCO officially withdrew its troops and closed its base in Nyamilima (Bwisha, Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu), triggering concerns of locals in the midst of the M23 resurgence in the area.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Rwanda (1994-)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 24 October 2022, in the midst of the 20-30 October resumption of M23 clashes, a Rwandan soldier surrendered to MONUSCO in Kiwanja (Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu). The soldier deserted the 401st battalion based in Kingi in Rwanda on 16 October 2022 and claimed that he didn't want to fight nor to return to Rwanda. He was handed over by the MONUSCO to FARDC on 4 November 2022.

ACTOR1: Twirwaneho Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Banyamulenge Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)

NOTES: Around 22 October 2022, a Twirwaneho combatant surrendered to MONUSCO in Minembwe (Lulenge, Fizi, Sud-Kivu) before being transferred to Uvira transit site on 22 October 2022.

ACTOR1: M23: March 23 Movement
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 20 October 2022, M23 shelled MONUSCO base in Kabindi (Bwisha, Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu) from their positions in Shwema hills. Casualties unknown.

NOTES: On 7 October 2022, a Twirwaneho-Makanika-Gumino-Android clashed with the MONUSCO at the UN base in Minembwe (Lulenge, Fizi, Sud-Kivu). It is the second clash in a week time. No fatalities on the UN side. Casualties unknown on the Mayi Mayi front.

NOTES: On 30 September 2022, Twirwaneho-Makanika killed a Pakistani MONUSCO blue helmet as they were approaching the MONUSCO base in Minembwe (Lulenge, Fizi, Sud-Kivu), supposedly to demobilize.

ACTOR1: CODECO-URDPC: Cooperative for Development of Congo (Union of Revolutionaries for the Defense of the Congolese People)

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
SOURCE: Kivu Security Tracker; Bunia Actualite; Radio Okapi; Mediacongo.net; Politico (DRC); Election-Net
NOTES: On 28 September 2022, CODECO-URDPC clashed against MONUSCO and FARDC in Pangapanga, on the outskirts of Gina (Djugu, Ituri), as CODECO was attacking civilians and heading for an IDP camp. CODECO killed two farmers and wounded a woman before MONUSCO and FARDC intervened and the militiamen retreated to their bastion of Sesele.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: Mayi Mayi Militia (Biloze Bishambuke)
NOTES: Around 20 September 2022 (from 13 - 28 September), following an agreement between MONUSCO and the group leadership, 26 children (including 5 girls) aged 14 to 17 left the Mayi Mayi Biloze Bishambuke in Mwenga territory (coded territorial capital Mwenga, Mwenga, Sud-Kivu). The children had initially been recruited between January 2019 and April 2022 in various parts of Mwenga territory.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-); Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
SOURCE: 7 Sur 7; La Prosperite; Politico (DRC); Actualite; Twitter; Reuters; Mediacongo.net; Bunia Actualite; La Libre Afrique; MONUSCO
NOTES: On 6 September 2022, rioters on motorbikes threw projectiles and set up barricades (means not specified) to prevent a MONUSCO convoy of 17 vehicles coming from Butembo to pass in Beni (Nord-Kivu). Blocked on Nyamwisi boulevard by the rioters, the blue helmets of the Tanzanian contingent, alongside the Police and the FARDC, who escorted the convoy, replied with warning shots. One rioter got killed and two injured. The incident triggered further tensions in the city. The MONUSCO convoy was returning from patrolling.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 2 September 2022, locals threw projectiles at MONUSCO vehicles in Kapalay (also spelled as Kapalayi) (Walendu Bindi, Irumu, Ituri) after a MONUSCO vehicle accidentally killed two people traveling on a motorbike. Other sources mentioned that the accident only involved 2 motorbikes but was interpreted otherwise by locals.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 2 September 2022, locals assaulted a MONUSCO vehicle in Geti (Walendu Bindi, Irumu, Ituri) whilst the MONUSCO was bringing the corpses of two victims accidentally killed in Kapalay/Kapalayi (riot in Kapalayi coded separately). Rioters tried to burn down the MONUSCO vehicles before the blue helmets fired warning shots to disperse the crowd.

ACTOR1: M23: March 23 Movement
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 31 August 2022, M23 ambushed a MONUSCO convoy 11 km south east of Rutshuru (Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu). Casualties unknown.

ACTOR1: Mayi Mayi Militia (Union of Patriots for the Defense of the Innocents)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 26 August 2022, 8 Mayi Mayi UPDI surrendered to the MONUSCO DDR section in Kanyabayonga (Bwito, Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu). They surrendered with two firearms and 200 cartridges.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
SOURCE: La Prunelle; MNCTV Congo; Radio Okapi
NOTES: On 25 August 2022, rioters blocked a convoy of MONUSCO blue helmets trying to enter Kiwanja (Rutshuru, Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu). FARDC intervened and fired shots, wounding two civilians. Rioters carrying bladed weapons kept trying to enter the MONUSCO base through the night.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Kenya (2013-2022)
NOTES: Movement of forces: On 22 August 2022, 200 Kenyans military officers and soldiers were deployed in east DRC (coded to Goma, Nord-Kivu) so as to reinforce the MONUSCO contingent of blue helmets.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 20 August 2022, pedestrians and motorcyclists stoned a MONUSCO convoy in Goma (Nord-Kivu). Both blue helmets and UN public servants were part of the convoy. The rioters chased the convoy. Meanwhile, civil society hold a petition to demand the departure of the MONUSCO. The organization Veranga Mutsanga expressed support to the authors of the mob.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Movement of forces: On 18 August 2022, MONUSCO forces alongside civilian staff members temporarily left Butembo headquarters (Nord-Kivu) two weeks after the anti-MONUSCO protests. Several sources reported that they had left for good before the information was denied by the UN mission.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: Twirwaneho Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Ngumino Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo); Mayi Mayi Militia (Buhirwa); Banyamulenge Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
NOTES: Around 15 August 2022 (month of), 20 Twirwaneho, Ngumino and Buhira combatants surrendered to MONUSCO in Sud-Kivu (coded to Minembwe, Lulenge, Fizi, Sud-Kivu) and more specifically in Mikenge/Itombwe in Mwenga territory, in Minembwe in Fizi territory and in Kahololo in Uvira territory. They handed over 11 small sized weapons as well as war ammunitions.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Mayi Mayi Militia (Baraka)
ACTOR2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-); MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
SOURCE: Kivu Security Tracker; Kivu Times; Radio Okapi; Election-Net; Politico (DRC); Twitter; 7 Sur 7; Cas-Info; Actualite; Reuters
NOTES: On 12 August 2022, Mayi Mayi Baraka shot dead six security forces (five police and one FARDC) between Butembo - Kangote and Butembo - Furu (Butembo, Butembo, Nord-Kivu) during a demonstration against insecurity in the city in the wake of a prison break (coded separately). At least three other policemen were wounded, one of whom died of his injuries two weeks later. The riot started when rioters blocked a MONUSCO convoy tried entering the city to bring foodstuff to their staff. Rioters also stole eight weapons from security forces, burned four police vehicles and erected barricades (means unspecified), demanding money from vehicles wishing to pass. 7 fatalities.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: LUCHA: Fight for Change
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
SOURCE: 7 Sur 7; BBC News; Election-Net; La Prunelle; Twitter
NOTES: On 5 August 2022, hundreds to more than 5,000 rioters, including from LUCHA, marched in Goma (Goma, Goma, Nord-Kivu) to pay tribute to the civilians who died in anti-MONUSCO demonstrations the previous weeks. An altercation broke out between the rioters and peacekeepers as the procession marched by a MONUSCO base on its way to the cemetery. Rioters also chanted anti-MONUSCO songs and called for the departure of the UN mission, promising to continue the demonstrations after the burial.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: Civilians (Democratic Republic of Congo)
SOURCE: Twitter; Bunia Actualite; RFI; France24; Daily Monitor (Uganda); Mediacongo.net; 7 Sur 7; SOS Medias; Deutsche Welle; Election-Net; AP; AFP; La Prunelle; Reuters; Radio Okapi; Actualite; BBC News; MONUSCO; La Libre Afrique; MNCTV Congo
NOTES: On 31 July 2022, MONUSCO soldiers from leave in Uganda opened fire at Congolese military and police forces at the border between Uganda and DR Congo in Kasindi (Beni, Nord-Kivu) before opening the barrier and crossing into DR Congo. There was an exchange of fire, leaving at least 2 Congolese dead and 15 others injured. According to authorities, UN soldiers were dressed in a manner that confused the border security suspecting the soldiers with rebels.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 28 July 2022, rioters set up barricades (means unspecified) on several main roads of Beni (Beni, Beni, Nord-Kivu) as they were demonstrating against the MONUSCO. The rioters threw petrol bombs at the MONUSCO base (assumed from MONUSCO forces). Gunshots were heard from the base as approximately a hundred rioters were trying to approach it, following which the rioters dispersed.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-); Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-); Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-) Republican Guard
SOURCE: Election-Net; 7 Sur 7; ReliefWeb; SOS Medias; Top Congo FM; Actualite; Politico (DRC); Radio Okapi; Mediacongo.net; BBC News; La Libre Afrique; Kivu Times; MNCTV Congo; Reuters; France24; Twitter; AFP; La Prunelle
NOTES: On 26 July 2022, hundreds of rioters, mostly youth, resumed violent demonstrations against MONUSCO in Goma (Nord-Kivu). Rioters burnt tires, set up barricades and road blocks with rocks and woods on Goma main roads. They ransack an ex-combatant transit camp and one MONUSCO base, called TMK, and looted all sorts of goods. They also gathered at the main MONUSCO site in the city center where they attempted to enter. They also attempted to break into the UNDP office. In the city, rioters burnt a mini bus. Important deployment of security forces, including the Republican Guard, police and military, who fired warning shots and tear gas to disperse the crowds. MONUSCO soldiers were accused of using live weapons to shoot at rioters. All activities were paralyzed in the city. 13 fatalities split over three days of demonstrations in Goma. At least 50 civilians injured.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-); Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
SOURCE: Mediacongo.net; Reuters; Radio Okapi; Rwanda News Agency; Twitter; La Prunelle; AFP; Xinhua; AP; La Libre Afrique; La Prosperite; Election-Net; Actualite; Top Congo FM; MONUSCO; SOS Medias
NOTES: On 26 July 2022, rioters gathered in front of MONUSCO base in Butembo (Nord-Kivu) to demonstrate against the presence of the UN mission in the country. Heavy deployment of security forces (assumed police and military) used tear gas to disperse the crowd and prevent any intrusion within the base. 9 civilians were killed. 4 UN security officers were killed with weapons seized from police. A report mentions a blue helmet was accidentally shot by another UN police officer. FARDC accused the Mayi Mayi Militia (Kyandenga) of organizing and supporting the attack against MONUSCO. One UN security force soldier was seriously injured.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-); Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
SOURCE: BBC News; Reuters; AFP; SOS Medias; La Prunelle; Actualite; Top Congo FM; Election-Net; Rwanda News Agency; Radio Okapi; France24; ReliefWeb; 7 Sur 7; MNCTV Congo; AP; Virunga Business Radio; RFI; Xinhua; Politico (DRC); Twitter; La Libre Afrique; Mediacongo.net; Kivu Times
NOTES: On 25 July 2022, hundreds of rioters, mostly youth, demonstrated against MONUSCO in Goma (Nord-Kivu). Rioters responded to the call of a youth wing of the UDPS to demonstrate against MONUSCO. They burnt tires, set up barricades and roadblocks with rocks and pebbles. Rioters also broke into three MONUSCO sites where they ransacked offices and looted goods. A source claims that some FARDC officers also looted goods. Several cars and offices were partially stoned and burnt. UN staff was evacuated by helicopters. Blue helmets intervened with tear gas to disperse the crowd within their bases before the arrival of FARDC. Police dispersed the rioters in the city with warning shots and teargas. 13 fatalities split over three days of demonstrations in Goma. At least 50 were injured. Some reports accused MONUSCO soldiers of having shot dead two rioters. Other sources also mention that peacekeepers were shooting at rioters which the UN denies. According to a civil society organization, Veranda Mutsanga, 7 people got killed by blue helmets during the unrest. Several rioters were arrested. The city mayor previously prohibited the demonstration.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: Civilians (Democratic Republic of Congo)
NOTES: On 13 July 2022, overnight, MONUSCO peacekeepers from the South African contingent fired live ammunitions at civilians who were following their vehicles in Tongbe village, coded to nearby Geti (Walendu Bindi, Irumu, Ituri). One civilian died and 4 were injured. Some sources report that the residents were trying to block the convoy of vehicles because they thought it was gold miners whose presence in the area they oppose.

ACTOR2: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
NOTES: On 9 July 2022, MONUSCO clashed against ADF in Busiyo (Irumu, Ituri), after the group attacked civilians in the village (coded separately). The rebels withdrew from the village. Casualties unknown.

NOTES: Other: On 30 June 2022, MONUSCO officially withdrew its troops and closed its offices in Tanganyika province (coded to provincial capital Kalemie), considering the security situation has improved enough.

NOTES: On 1 February 2022, the FARDC and MONUSCO forces clashed against presumed CODECO-URDPC as they killed at least 52 IDPs/refugees of the Hema community (mainly women and at least 15 children), and wounded 30 to 60 (by machete) at a site known as Plaine Savo (Bahema-Badjere, Djugu, Ituri). Other sources suggest that over 60 people were killed. At least 3,000 people were displaced as a result of this attack, although other sources suggest that the number of displaced is much higher.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Movement of forces: On 28 January 2022, the MONUSCO withdrew its military base in Gina (Djugu, Ituri). This was a temporary base established on 23 October 2021 (coded as another event).

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
NOTES: Around 28 January 2022 (as reported), the MONUSCO (Ukranian peacekeepers) carried out airstrikes against the ADF near Bunia (Bunia, Ituri). Casualties unknown.

ACTOR1: CODECO: Cooperative for Development of Congo
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 20 January 2022, the CODECO attacked a base of the MONUSCO in Roe (Djugu, Ituri). The MONUSCO pushed out the assailants. There were no casualties.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: CODECO: Cooperative for Development of Congo

The clashes took place during a security operation to protect civilians. 10 CODECO members were killed and several others were injured. 1 MONUSCO blue helmet was injured. The MONUSCO pushed out the group from the area (unclear whether there was a transfer of territory).

NOTES: Movement of forces: On 18 January 2022, the MONUSCO withdrew from Djalasiga, chiefdom of Alur Djuganda, Mahagi territory (Ituri), after a group of young people pushed it out of the area. There were no reported clashes/rioting activity.

ACTOR1: CODECO-URDPC: Cooperative for Development of Congo (Union of Revolutionaries for the Defense of the Congolese People)

NOTES: On 12 January 2022, the MONUSCO opened a tempory base in Drodro (Djugu, Ituri), following CODECO attacks in this area.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Movement of forces: On 8 January 2022, the MONUSCO closed off its base in Bibokobobo/Bibogobobo (Fizi, Sud-Kivu). The was base was installed in October 2012 following atrocities in the region (coded as another event).

NOTES: On 7 January 2022, the CODECO-URDPC fighters attacked the MONUSCO in the village of Djangi (Djugu, Ituri). Casualties unknown.

NOTES: On 7 January 2022, CODECO-URDPC clashed with MONUSCO peacekeepers in Ndjangi (Bahema-Nord, Djugu, Ituri). MONUSCO were able to push back CODECO-URDPC. Casualties unknown.

The MONUSCO fired shots in the air to disperse the group. Subsequent reports suggest the group was protesting against the MONUSCO after one of its vehicles hit and killed a motorcycle taxi driver (assumed accidental). The FARDC eventually came to restore order at the scene.

NOTES: Around 22 November 2021 (as reported), the MONUSCO installed a temporary base in Drodro (Djugu, Ituri), following attacks by the CODECO-URDPC in the area on 21-22 November (coded as other events).

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Around 3 November 2021 (as reported), the MONUSCO established a temporary base in the locality of Bibogobobo (Fizi, Sud-Kivu) to facilitate the repatriation of IDPs from Baraka to their villages near this area.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 23 October 2021, the MONUSCO established temporary bases in Djugu and Jina/Gina (Djugu, Ituri), in response to CODECO attacks.

The clashes were triggered by an ADF attack on a convoy escorted by the FARDC/MONUSCO. 4-6 cars were reportedly burnt and several people are missing. The ISCAP claimed the event, reporting 6 fatalities. The fatalities could not be independently verified.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)

SOURCE: MONUSCO; Bunia Actualite; Twitter; BBC News; Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo; La Prunelle; Nashir; Xinhua
NOTES: On 26 September 2021, the FARDC/MONUSCO clashed against presumed ADF/FPIC fighters in Makayanga (Irumu, Ituri), where at least 1-16 members of the group were killed and others detained. Other sources suggest that 12 civilians were also killed during the clashes. The ISCAP claimed the attack, killing several FARDC officers and burning of barracks. 10-40 rebels, including FPIC/FRPI, were detained. The FPIC burnt the house of a journalist.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
SOURCE: SOS Medias; Kivu Security Tracker; Xinhua; Radio Okapi; AFP; Actualite; La Prunelle; ICRC
NOTES: On 23 September 2021, the FARDC and the MONUSCO reportedly clashed against presumed ADF fighters who attacked the localities of Bogi (Irumu, Ituri), as well as Kipe ya Yo, Vingazi and Komanda town (coded as other events). Overall, at least 5 people were killed, including civilians and 1 rebel, and others kidnapped (including a Red Cross worker). Further, shops of merchants and 33-36 houses were burnt/looted. The group was in possession of automatic rifles and spoke broken Swahili. 5 fatalities spread across three events.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)

NOTES: On 23 September 2021, the FARDC and the MONUSCO reportedly clashed against presumed ADF fighters who attacked the localities of Kipe ya Yo and Vingazi, located near Komanda town (Irumu, Ituri). The group was also attacked the town and the locality of Bogi (coded as other events). Overall, at least 5 people were killed, civilians and 1 rebel, and others kidnapped (including a Red Cross worker). Further, shops of merchants and 33-36 houses were burnt/looted. The group was in possession of automatic rifles and spoke broken Swahili. 5 fatalities spread across three events.

ACTOR1: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces

NOTES: On 23 September 2021, the FARDC and the MONUSCO reportedly clashed against presumed ADF fighters who attacked Komanda town (Irumu, Ituri), as well as other nearby localities (coded as other events). Overall, at least 5 people were killed (including civilians and 1 rebel) and others kidnapped (including a Red Cross worker). Further, shops of merchants and 33-36 houses were burnt/looted. The group was in possession of automatic rifles and spoke broken Swahili. 5 fatalities spread across three events. The ISCAP claimed the event in this location, killing 7 people (4 soldiers and 3 civilians) and burning buildings of Christians with mortar shells.

ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Agreement: Around 1 September 2021 (as reported), the head of the Mayi Mayi Perci Moto Moto handed over his weapons to the MONUSCO along with ten other members in the province of Sud-Kivu [coded as Bukavu].

ACTOR1: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
ACTOR2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
SOURCE: BBC News; MONUSCO; Reuters; Bunia Actualite; AP; Politico (DRC); Twitter; AFP; BPF; La Libre Afrique; Actualite; Telegram; Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo; Radio Okapi
NOTES: On 1 September 2021, the FARDC/MONUSCO clashed against suspected ADF militants after they ambushed a convoy of vehicles traveling with army protection near Ofai (Irumu, Ituri), between Komanda and Luna. Overall, at least 4 were killed (all of whom were men and refugees/IDPs) and 80-100 people were kidnapped. 14-18 vehicles were burnt down and 1 FARDC officer disappeared. The FARDC/MONUSCO eventually released 50-70 of the abducted victims, some of them in Mafifi. Community displacements were triggered. The ISCAP claimed the event, targeting Christians.

Sources suggest some of the fighters disarmed in Walikale-centre, near Pinga, and in Kibua. There is a divergence of knowledge on whether the General of the group actually disarmed or whether he was only there to accompany his fighters.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)

NOTES: On 8 August 2021, the FARDC/MONUSCO regained territory of Haie/Haye I and Haie/Haye II, located in the valley of Mwalika (Beni, Nord-Kivu) after bombarding the ADF militants, resulting in at least 45 fatalities from the ADF side. The army reports this was the training bastion of the ADF. They also attacked other nearby areas, including Lusilubi, Nzelube, Semuliki and Talya rivers.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 12 July 2021, MONUSCO peacekeepers established a temporary base in Kamandi Gite, located west of Lake Edward (Lubero, Nord-Kivu) to monitor the security situation in the region.

ACTOR2: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
NOTES: Defusal: On 7 July 2021, the MONUSCO dismantled an artisanal bomb, which was planted by an unidentified armed group, in the agglomeration of Alimbongo (Lubero, Nord-Kivu). No injuries and/or fatalities were reported.

The UNMAS destroyed the explosive. Sources suspect that the ADF planted the device. Another bomb was reportedly discovered at a classroom in this neighborhood.

SOURCE: BBC News; Radio Okapi; HumAngle; AFP; Twitter; Bunia Actualite

The group had gathered in the locality based on rumours that ADF militants were being transported to the area. Gun shots were fired and 1 person was killed. At least four people were injured.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Movement of forces: On 30 June 2021, the MONUSCO withdrew from the province of Kasai Central [coded as Kananga].

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Movement of forces: On 30 June 2021, the MONUSCO withdrew from the province of Kasai [coded as Tshikapa].

NOTES: On 23 June 2021, the CODECO attacked the MONUSCO base in the village of Rho/Roe (Djugu, Ituri). Reports suggest that the CODECO was attempting an attack against civilians who were seeking refuge at the MONUSCO base. The MONUSCO repelled the attackers. No injuries and/or fatalities were reported.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: CODECO-URDPC: Cooperative for Development of Congo (Union of Revolutionaries for the Defense of the Congolese People)
SOURCE: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo; Kivu Security Tracker; UNOCHA; Politico (DRC)
NOTES: On 14 June 2021, the FARDC/MONUSCO attacked the CODECO-URDPC in the village of Fataki (Djugu, Ituri). The FARDC/MONUSCO drove the militiamen out of the village. During the clashes on this day, 21 CODECO-URDPC were killed. Overall, some reports suggest that, during the 5-day clash, at least 42 militiamen were killed as well as 2 FARDC soldiers. 8,000 people were displaced as a result of the clashes, the majority of whom sought refuge at the MONUSCO in Djaiba.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
SOURCE: 7 Sur 7; Kivu Security Tracker; Radio Okapi; Politico (DRC); Bunia Actualite; Actualite
NOTES: On 7 June 2021, the FARDC, along with the MONUSCO, clashed against the ADF in the villages of Boga and Kinyanjojo (Irumu, Ituri). During the attacks, at least 12 people were killed (2 of whom were ADF militants), 3 medical compounds were burnt, several civilians were abducted, 1 FARDC soldier was injured, and one grave was desecrated. 2 AK47 weapons were recovered. Some sources suggest the attack was carried out by the ADF in coalition with a Hutu-led group, the Banyabwisha. Community displacements were triggered. 12 fatalities coded across two events.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
SOURCE: 7 Sur 7; Kivu Security Tracker; Actualite; Politico (DRC); Bunia Actualite; Radio Okapi
NOTES: On 7 June 2021, the FARDC, along with the MONUSCO, clashed against the ADF in the villages of Kinyanjojo and Boga (Irumu, Ituri). Initially, during the attacks, at least 12 people were killed (2 of whom were ADF militants), 3 medical compounds were burnt, several civilians were abducted, 1 FARDC soldier was injured, and one grave was desecrated. 2 AK47 weapons were recovered. On 20 June, at least 23 bodies of civilians, which were reportedly killed on this day, were recovered in Boga and Tshabi (coded as another event). Some sources suggest the attack was carried out by the ADF in coalition with a Hutu-led group, the Banyabwisha. Community displacements were triggered. In total, with the 20 June body discovery, at least 18 fatalities took place.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Tanzania (1964-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Movement of forces: Around 2 June 2021 (week of), Tanzanian forces, which are part of the MONUSCO, arrived in Beni to support the State of Siege operation by the Congolese government, which took effect on 6 May.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
SOURCE: Kivu Security Tracker; Twitter; UN (unspecified); AFP; Africa 1; ReliefWeb; La Prunelle; Actualite; Radio Okapi; Bunia Actualite
NOTES: On 31 May 2021, the FARDC/MONUSCO clashed against an unidentified armed group in the village of Tshabi (Irumu, Ituri), while the said group killed 23-28 people in the village (including 4 women, 15 men, and 4 children) and kidnapped 10 others. The group also attacked the villages of Boga, Rubingo and Kinyanjojo (coded as other events). Altogether, 48000 were displaced and 27 others were abducted. Some sources speculate that the attack was carried out by the ADF, while others say it may have been an ethnic clash between the Nyali and Banyabwisha.

NOTES: On 13 May 2021, the ADF reportedly attacked the FARDC, along with reported Ugandan/Kenyan forces (assumed MONUSCO), in the village of Halungupa (Beni, Nord-Kivu). Several soldiers were wounded. The ISCAP claimed the event.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
NOTES: On 12 May 2021, the MONUSCO targeted ADF bases with airstrikes in the city of Beni (Beni, Nord-Kivu). Casualties unknown. However, reports suggest that the air strikes led to ADF displacements from the centre to the south of the region, allowing the FARDC to identify them near the Beni-Kasindi axis.

The civilians were reportedly ambushed while carrying a civilian dead body who was killed in Bwerere. The motorcycle was burnt. The body of the driver was found in this location the next day.

ACTOR2: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
SOURCE: Actualite; AFP; Al Naba; Election-Net; Kivu Security Tracker; La Libre Afrique; Radio Okapi
NOTES: Around 10 May 2021, the FARDC reportedly killed 8-10 ADF militants in Halungupa (Beni, Nord-Kivu). Other sources by the ISCAP, however, point out that the clash involved another set of actors on the side of the FARDC, including Kenyan and Somalian forces (likely MONUSCO). The ISCAP claimed the event.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: CODECO: Cooperative for Development of Congo
SOURCE: BBC News; Radio Okapi; Bunia Actualite
NOTES: Around 1 May 2021, the FARDC, in cooperation with Bangladeshi elements of the MONUSCO, clashed against the CODECO in the locality of Kasibana/Kasingbana, located near Amee (Djugu, Ituri), following an attempted incursion by the armed group to the community. Reports suggest that the MONUSCO repelled the militiamen, who fled with 23 goats. No injuries and/or fatalities were reported.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 27 April 2021, a group of people barricaded the road to block MONUSCO vehicles in the Benengule neighborhood of Beni (Beni, Nord-Kivu). Shots were reportedly fired, injuring two people. No reason for the demonstration reported.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Movement of forces: On 26 April 2021, a MONUSCO unit left its base in the locality of Kipupu (Mwenga, Sud-Kivu). Reports suggest that they moved to Uvira. The motive behind the movement of forces is unknown.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: Civilians (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Taxi Drivers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
NOTES: On 24 April 2021, two Chinese elements of the MONUSCO reportedly tortured and injured a Congolese RVA driver in the airport of Kavumu (Kabare, Sud-Kivu). An investigation into the events was subsequently launched by the MONUSCO. Other reports suggest that the event took place in the Bukavu airport.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: Mayi Mayi Militia
NOTES: Around 22 April 2021, the FARDC/MONUSCO clashed against a Mayi Mayi group (faction unknown) in the village of Mulo (Lubero, Nord-Kivu). Reports suggest that the army repelled the assailants. 1 FARDC soldier was killed.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: Chini Ya Kilima-FPIC: Patriotic and Integrationist Force of Congo
NOTES: On 22 April 2021, the FARDC and MONUSCO clashed against the FPIC in the village of Marabo (Ituri, Irumu). 11-17 FPIC militants were killed and 7-9 others were captured. 4 weapons were recovered by the FARDC. Reports suggest that the militants were pushed out of the village.

ACTOR1: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Ndarumanga)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Agreement: On 21 April 2021, the Head of the Mayi Mayi Raia Mutomboki-Ndarumanga, along with 33-40 other militiamen, handed over their weapons to the MONUSCO in Maimingi (Shabunda, Sud-Kivu). 25 weapons were recovered.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: Mayi Mayi Militia
SOURCE: Kivu Security Tracker; Actualite; La Prunelle; Radio Okapi
NOTES: Around 20 April 2021, the FARDC clashed against a Mayi Mayi group (faction unknown) at the airfield of Butembo (Lubero, Nord-Kivu), located in the Rughenda neighborhood, after the armed group attacked a military and MONUSCO base. Reports suggest that these militiamen were armed with guns and knives. During the clashes, 4 militiamen were killed, including 1 woman.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: Chini Ya Kilima-FPIC: Patriotic and Integrationist Force of Congo
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Bira Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
SOURCE: Bunia Actualite; Kivu Security Tracker; MNCTV Congo; Radio Okapi; Twitter
NOTES: On 18 April 2021, the FARDC clashed against the FPIC/Chini ya Kilima (reportedly of the Bira ethnic group) in the villages of Balingina, Nyankunde and Marabo (Irumu, Ituri). 10 people were killed in Marabo (5 Chini ya Kilima-FPIC, 2 FARDC and 3 civilians), where around 30 vehicles were looted and 5 burnt. 10 other civilians were wounded in the clashes. The FARDC, in cooperation with the MONUSCO, pushed out FPIC from the village of Marabo. Community displacements were triggered. 10 fatalities across three events.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: CODECO-URDPC: Cooperative for Development of Congo (Union of Revolutionaries for the Defense of the Congolese People)
NOTES: On 17 April 2021, the FARDC clashed against the CODECO-URDPC in Sanduku (Djugu, Ituri), after the armed group attacked a military base in the area. Nepalese peacekeepers from MONUSCO assisted the FARDC in repelling the attackers. No injuries and/or fatalities.

ACTOR1: CODECO-URDPC: Cooperative for Development of Congo (Union of Revolutionaries for the Defense of the Congolese People)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 16 April 2021, CODECO-URDPC fighters clashed against MONUSCO peacekeepers in the village of Yikpa (Djugu, Ituri). The CODECO-URDPC killed 1 person and set houses on fire. Reports suggest that MONUSCO peacekeepers drove off the militiamen from the village.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: CODECO-URDPC: Cooperative for Development of Congo (Union of Revolutionaries for the Defense of the Congolese People)
NOTES: On 14 April 2021, MONUSCO peacekeepers attacked CODECO-URDPC militiamen in the village of Fataki (Djugu, Ituri). Reports suggest that MONUSCO drove off the CODECO-URDPC from the village. In the attack, 8 militiamen were killed, as well as 9 civilians, and livestock was looted. Threats were made on the Catholic Parish in the village.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 9 April 2021, a group of rioters burned two bridges in the neighborhood of Mbimbi in Oicha (Oicha, Beni) to block the passage of MONUSCO vehicles in the area, during a demonstration against the recrudescence of ADF attacks in the region and to demand the departure of the MONUSCO, who they accuse of mishandling the security situation in the Eastern part of the country. Reports suggest that 1 person was killed by MONUSCO and another one was injured.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
SOURCE: Actualite; Al Naba; BPF; Election-Net; La Prunelle; Radio Okapi
NOTES: On 9 April 2021, MONUSCO reportedly killed 1 element of the ADF in the village of Kilia (Beni, Nord-Kivu), following a double ADF attack against civilians in Kilia and Makisabo that resulted in 5-7 male civilian casualties, 1 ADF casualty and 1-2 injuries. 6 fatalities coded across two events. The ISCAP reportedly claimed the attack.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 7 April 2021, a group of people in the city of Beni (Beni, Nord-Kivu) attempted to intercept several military vehicles of the MONUSCO that were coming from Kasindi. In response, the FARDC fired shots to disperse the rioters, who were demanding the departure of the MONUSCO in the light of increased ADF attacks in the region.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 7 April 2021, a group of people erected barricades to block the passage of MONUSCO vehicles in Kasindi (Beni, Nord-Kivu). The group was demonstrating to demand the departure of the MONUSCO, who they accuse of mishandling the security situation in the Eastern part of the country. Reports suggest that the FARDC intervened in the demonstration, firing a shot which resulted in the killing of 1 person.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 5 April 2021, a group of people blocked traffic along the national route no.27 at the level of Lopa (Djugu, Ituri) to demonstrate against the recrudescence of criminality/insecurity in the area as well as the illegal barriers erected by CODECO militiamen. A passing MONUSCO convoy was targeted with projectiles, who fired shots in response. No injuries and/or fatalities were reported.

ACTOR1: Mayi Mayi Militia (Prospere)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Agreement: On 29 March 2021, 6 Mayi Mayi Prospere militants handed over their weapons to MONUSCO authorities in Kiringye (Uvira, Sud-Kivu), including 2 AK 47 weapons and 32 war ammunitions. Other sources point out that the disarmament took place in Sange (Fizi, Sud-Kivu).

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
SOURCE: Actualite; Bunia Actualite; MNCTV Congo; Radio Okapi; Twitter
NOTES: On 21 March 2021, a group of young people burned car tires and blocked national road number 27 in this area, including a vehicle from an agency of the United Nations, which was coming back from the city in Iga Barriere (Djugu, Ituri), in response to CODECO-FDBC activity at a commercial center in the area.

ACTOR1: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
ACTOR2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)

SOURCE: Twitter; Kivu Security Tracker; Radio Okapi
NOTES: On 26 February 2021, elements of the FARDC, as well as MONUSCO troops, clashed against ADF militiamen on the route of Beni-Kasindi near Makisabo (Beni, Nord-Kivu). The ADF killed 3 civilians during the incursion, before the FARDC and MONUSCO intervened. Subsequent reports suggest that ISCAP claimed the attack.

ACTOR1: Mayi Mayi Militia (Makanika)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Ngumino Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo); Banyamulenge Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo); Twirwaneho Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Agreement: Around 15 February 2021 (month of), 6 Makanika militiamen (Ngumino-Twigwaheno coalition) handed over their weapons to MONUSCO authorities in Mikenge (Mwenga, Sud-Kivu). 3 AK47 weapons and 130 munitions were handed over. Five days later, on 20 February 2021, 5 Makanika militants disarmed in the same location. 4 AK47 were retrieved in that occasion, as well as 162 ammunitions. Six days later, on 26 February, 2 other Makanika militiamen disarmed in Mikenge (Mwenga, Sud-Kivu). 1 AK47 was retrieved at that point.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Headquarters or base established: On 29 January 2021, the MONUSCO reopened a UN military base in Kipupu village (Mwenga, Sud-Kivu). The reason of this deployment was to increase the protection of civilians following a surge of clashes between armed groups in the High Plateaus area.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: Mayi Mayi Militia (Hapa na pale)

NOTES: Agreement: On 15 January 2021, 6 Mayi-Mayi Hapa na pale rebels (Batwa ethnic militia) surrendered and handed over their arms to the FARDC and the MONUSCO in Butondo village (Nyunzu, Tanganyika). They joined the demobilization process.

ACTOR1: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
ACTOR2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
SOURCE: La Prunelle; UNSC; Actualite; Twitter; 7 Sur 7; MNCTV Congo; Kivu Security Tracker; La Libre Afrique; BBC News
NOTES: On 28 December 2020, the FARDC, with the support of the MONUSCO, clashed with ADF rebels in Loselose village (Beni, Nord-Kivu), during an attack by the rebels against FARDC barracks. 2 FARDC soldiers were killed and 6 others were injured. From the ADF ranks, 5 combatants were killed, and 6 others injured. The FARDC, which had military aerial support, managed to repel the attackers. ISCAP claimed the attack and said they had killed 4 soldiers and injured another. Subsequent reports suggest that, during the incursion, the ADF killed 7 civilians and 12 FARDC soldiers, effectively occupying the area of Loselose which the FARDC forces later regained on 1 January with MONUSCO support.

ACTOR1: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-); MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 27 December 2020, a group of youths blocked a joint patrol of the FARDC, the police and the MONUSCO, to prevent them from heading to the Rwangoma district of Beni town (Beni, Nord-Kivu). Despite the warning shots in the air fired by the security forces to make a way through, the group confronted them, resulting in an army jeep vandalized and a police motorcycle burned. The security forces arrested 10 people. The youths accused the security forces of inaction and of being complicit in the insecurity in Beni.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)

NOTES: Agreement: On 15 December 2020, 250 rebels from rival militias, Mayi-Mayi Hapa na pale (Batwa ethnic militia) and Bantu ethnic militias, surrendered and handed over their arms to the FARDC and the MONUSCO in Kyata village, near Pende village (Nyunzu, Tanganyika). They joined the demobilization process.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: Mayi Mayi Militia
NOTES: Agreement: On 8 December 2020, 30 minor boys and 1 girl from a local Mayi-Mayi militia (group not reported), aged between 14 and 17 years, were handed over by their superiors to the child protection section of the MONUSCO in Kalunguta locality (Beni, Nord-Kivu). The children were referred to reintegration centers.

ACTOR1: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-); MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 7 November 2020, local Christian groups together with local authorities, civil society organizations and the MONUSCO marched in Rusthuru town (Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu) against the rise of intercommunal violence and tribalism. The march was a response to recent deadly clashes between Nandes and Hutus and its associated militias.

NOTES: On 26 October 2020, the FARDC with the support of the MONUSCO clashed with CODECO's ALC faction for the third day in Zumbe village (Djugu, Ituri). No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

The FARDC drove the rebels out of the village. Overall, at least 20 rebels and 4 FARDC soldiers were killed and 6 soldiers were seriously injured in this village and others during two-day clashes. Fatalities coded across 8 events.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
NOTES: On 4 October 2020, 43 Batwa combatants from the Fimbo faction (including children), which belongs to the Hapa na pale militia, surrendered to the MONUSCO and the FARDC in Nsela village (Kalemie, Tanganyika) and joined the DDR process. These rebels, including their commander called Mundusi, handed over 32 firearms.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 18 September 2020, the MONUSCO closed its main base in Kindu (Kindu, Maniema), as part of its progressive retreat operation from the less conflicted areas. This UN Mission handed over most of all their equipment and material to the provincial authorities.

ACTOR1: Mayi Mayi Militia (Hapa na pale)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Batwa Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
ACTOR2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Around 16 September 2020 (week of), around 50 Batwa combatants from the Hapa na pale militia surrendered and handed over their arms to the FARDC and MONUSCO in Zongwe (Moba, Tanganyika).

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: Around 10 September 2020 (as reported), the MONUSCO established a UN military base in Mutwanga (Beni, Nord-Kivu), 8 years after it was dismantled. This deployment seeks to mitigate attacks by the ADF armed group in the area and protect local civilians.

ACTOR1: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
NOTES: Around 15 August 2020 (month of), a group of 63 Mayi-Mayi fighters of the Mazembe group surrendered to the MONUSCO and FARDC in Kanyabayonga (Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu), following the death of their leader, Kitete Bushu. The rebels, who left the bush sporadically, handed over more than 20 weapons.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Mayi Mayi Militia (Hapa na pale); Batwa Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
NOTES: Around 13 August 2020 (as reported), 32 Mayi Mayi Liwa combatants, a Batwa group which collaborates with Hapa na pale militia led by Mundus, surrendered in Lukwenge village, 30 Km from Bendera (Kalemie, Tanganyika), during a DDR mission (Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration) by MONUSCO and the FARDC. They handed over around 20 weapons.

The surrender took place after heavy clashes with the NDC-R faction led by Guidon. Some sources stated that Gilbert Bwira also surrendered, but it was not confirmed by the FARDC.

The surrender took place after heavy clashes with the NDC-R faction led by Guidon. Some sources stated that Gilbert Bwira also surrendered, but it was not confirmed by the FARDC.

ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 17 July 2020, around 25 militiamen from a Mayi-Mayi Mazembe faction surrendered to the MONUSCO in Kanyabayonga (Ruthsuru, Nord-Kivu) the day after their leader, Kitete Bushu, was killed by Mayi-Mayi Kabido armed men. They handed over 9 firearms and 1 rocket launcher.

The state forces drove off the rebels and the convoy continued escorted. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

ACTOR1: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
NOTES: On 3 July 2020, the ADF clashed with soldiers of MONUSCO and FARDC in Mukoko in the rural community of Oicha (Beni, Nord-Kivu) after the group attacked civilians in the road. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

ACTOR1: Mayi Mayi Militia (Hapa na pale)
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Mayi Mayi Militia (Kaomba)
ACTOR2: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 24 June 2020, 25 combatants from Mayi Mayi Hapa Na Pale and Mayi Mayi Kaomba militias handed over their weapons to the local authorities and the MONUSCO during a disarmament and demobilization ceremony in Kashege (Manono, Tanganyika). Overall, 21 AK-47 rifles, 3 shotguns as well as a large number of bows and arrows were handed over.

ACTOR1: CODECO: Cooperative for Development of Congo
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-); Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
NOTES: On 23 June 2020, CODECO militiamen clashed with MONUSCO at a UN base in Bayoo and MONUSCO, FARDC, and the police at Gali village, both near Bule village (Djugu, Ituri). The militia combatants were repelled by the state forces with the help of UN armored vehicles. A MONUSCO helicopter overflew the area to deter any potential attack against local civilians. No fatalities and/or injuries reported

ACTOR1: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
NOTES: On 22 June 2020, ADF militiamen clashed with MONUSCO troops on patrol in Makisabo village, a few Km from Kisima (Beni, Nord-Kivu), during an ambush carried out by the rebels which resulted in 1 blue helmet killed and another injured, both from the Indonesian battalion. Some other civilians went missing and more than 1,000 locals fled towards Beni. The assailants also destroyed 4 MONUSCO vehicles.

ACTOR1: Mayi Mayi Militia
ACTOR2: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)

Reportedly, the blue helmets opened fire when the rebels prevented them from patrolling the area.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: CODECO: Cooperative for Development of Congo
NOTES: On 3 June 2020, MONUSCO peacekeepers on patrol clashed with CODECO militiamen near Drodro village (Djugu, Ituri) when these rebels attempted to attack the camp for internal displaced people located at this village. The UN forces managed to drive off the assailants. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

ACTOR1: Mayi Mayi Militia (Biloze Bishambuke)
ACTOR2: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)

The rebels shot and injured between 3 and 8 camp residents who were then rescued by MONUSCO troops. Two rebels and 1 FARDC soldier were killed, and 2 MONUSCO peacekeepers were injured in the crossfire. The state forces managed to drive off the rebels, capturing 1 of them and recovering 89 cows they had looted.

ACTOR1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
ACTOR2: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)

Sources give different numbers but at least one police officer and four civilians have been killed. At least 16 civilians, 15 police officers and 5 FARDCs were injured. Around 20 civilians were arrested.

NOTES: On 31 October 2019, FARDC announced the launch of large-scale operations targeting domestic and foreign armed groups that operate in the Great Lake region, in the east of the country, in Beni, Butembo, Lubero, Nord-Kivu and Sud-Kivu. The offensive primarily targets the Ugandan ADF, but also Congolese Mayi Mayi groups and the Rwandan FDLR and the Burundese FNL. FARDC announced that operations will be supported by the MONUSCO.
